summary: Still bitter that the only Arya x Cat scene i am ever going to get is Arya and Lady Stone Heart. Every other Stark/Snow child...
body: Still bitter that the only Arya x Cat scene i am ever going to get is Arya and Lady Stone Heart. Every other Stark/Snow child gets a scene with Cat (except maybe Rickon), but not Arya.

reblog.comment: Still bitter that the only Arya x Cat scene i am ever going to get is Arya and Lady Stone Heart. Every other Stark/Snow child gets a scene with Cat (except maybe Rickon), but not Arya.

blog.name: asongofstarkandtargaryen
blog.title: Dracarys!
blog.description: Jon/Dany/Bran/Arya Stan. Salty about the got ending. Also likes: The 100,  Star Wars, Stranger Things.

tags: thinking about those two always makes me emotional
a post of ice and fire
summary: When Jon finds out the truth about lineage I want him to visit the Crypts of Winterfell once again to go to pay his respects to...
body:
When Jon finds out the truth about lineage I want him to visit the Crypts of Winterfell once again to go to pay his respects to Ned and Lyanna’s statues.

And I want Arya to accompany him on that visit and in front of their father’s grave to assure him that no matter who his real parents are for her he’ll always be a family. Because he’s her home just like she’s his heart.

blog.name: gendryaonline
blog.title: a nice oak tree
blog.description: a blog dedicated to arya stark and gendry from a song of ice and fire by george r.r. martin and hbo's game of thrones

summary: The two spearmen turned at the cry, and a third man came into view, shoving a captive before him. It was growing too dark to...
text:
The two spearmen turned at the cry, and a third man came into view, shoving a captive before him. It was growing too dark to make out faces, but the prisoner was wearing a shiny steel helm, and when Arya saw the horns she knew it was Gendry. You stupid stupid stupid STUPID! she thought. If he’d been here she would have kicked him again.

It didn’t matter. The only thing that mattered was that they had Gendry. Even if he was stubborn and stupid, she had to get him out. She wondered if they knew that the queen wanted him.One of the guards took off his helm and donned Gendry’s instead. It made her angry to see him wearing it, but she knew there was nothing she could do to stop him.

reblog.comment: a Clash of Kings

blog.name: fedonciadale
blog.title: FedonCiadale
blog.description: Fantasy aficionado since I read Tolkien in my teenage years. I still love Tolkien but I am also into other works. I love ASOIAF (books) and GoT (Show). I also like Brandon Sanderson, Lois McMaster Bujold, in short in my free time it's fantasy...Header by courtesy of ragekitn!

summary: GoT fandom really does miscontrue their takes on the Stark sisters' dynamic that I expected to read about Sansa pushing around...
question: GoT fandom really does miscontrue their takes on the Stark sisters' dynamic that I expected to read about Sansa pushing around A*rya or intentionally sabotaging her when reading AGOT. A lot of the hostile tension between the sisters start after the Trident fiasco and certain stans really love to use passages of Sansa's ill feelings towards A*rya post-trident when her anger comes from the death of her wolf and Sansa's own daddy issues.
answer:
(2) While Sansa’s hostility was harsh and misplaced, the fandom has greatly exaggerated this and has built up their entire dynamic solely by this event without exploring their relationship outside of it. Reading some passages of Sansa’s and Arya’s post AGOT, I got the impression that, while they weren’t close, they do love each other and think of each other fondly throughout their journey and I would love to read GRRM’s version of their reunion.

Dear nonny,

anyone who has siblings knows that they can be annoying as hell, different from yourself in almost every important way and still very dear to your heart. And anway while I thought it was perfectly acceptable to prank my older sister, I would have defended her against any other person! Now, that my sister and I are adults we actually have a very close and nice relationship and she has my back - and we are still very, very different.

I do think that part of the misunderstanding in regard to Arya and Sansa is due to the PoV trap. We see Sansa for the first time through Arya’s eyes, and it is obvious that Arya as the rebellious and unruly sister rejects the ease with which Sansa lives up to expectations. And honestly we can feel for her. The reason that some Arya fans hate Sansa is that they well remember this feeling of inadequacy that gets hold of you when you see another older girl excelling in things you yourself are not particularly good at and yet seem to be the only important activitiy for a woman. I guess in today’s society it is better than in the rigid society of almost-medieval Westeros, but I do believe that many, many people can relate to that particular feeling. It is part of growing up, that older children are better at some things, and coping with this and finding what we excel at is what makes us grow. So, Arya’s PoV is extremely relatable, but it is also unreliable, because her feelings positively hinder her to realise that Sansa is not a bad sister. In the very first Arya chapter, Sansa covers up for her - which she is accustomed to do.

“Jon says he looks like a girl,” Arya said.         

Sansa sighed as she stitched. “Poor Jon,” she said. “He gets jealous because he’s a bastard.”    

“He’s our brother,” Arya said, much too loudly. Her voice cut through the afternoon quiet of the tower room.          

Septa Mordane raised her eyes. She had a bony face, sharp eyes, and a thin lipless mouth made for frowning. It was frowning now. “What are you talking about, children?”                 

“Our half brother,” Sansa corrected, soft and precise. She smiled for the septa. “Arya and I were remarking on how pleased we were to have the princess with us today,” she said. (AGOT, Arya I)

Sansa deflects Septa Mordane. She prevents that everyone in the room gets alerted to the fact that Jon and Arya were criticizing the crown prince. She’s got Arya’s back here, but Arya doesn’t realise this.

Anyway, I could go on about this and you are quite right, that we have the incident at the Trident in the first Sansa chapter does not help at all. Some fans refuse to see that deep down Arya and Sansa love each other. I’m sure that @kellyvela and @lostlittlesatellites have explained this and you can check their blogs.

There is the PoV trap, there is the fact, that we see only into Sansa’s head the day the fall-out with her sister happens, and there is the way we are guided by that bastard GRRM to misread and misinterpret the signs that point towards the sisters’ love for each other.

She remembered a summer’s snow in Winterfell when Arya and Bran had ambushed her as she emerged from the keep one morning. They’d each had a dozen snowballs to hand, and she’d had none. Bran had been perched on the roof of the covered bridge, out of reach, but Sansa had chased Arya through the stables and around the kitchen until both of them were breathless. She might even have caught her, but she’d slipped on some ice. Her sister came back to see if she was hurt. When she said she wasn’t, Arya hit her in the face with another snowball, but Sansa grabbed her leg and pulled her down and was rubbing snow in her hair when Jory came along and pulled them apart, laughing. (ASOS, Sansa VII)

This is where you can see it. The younger siblings prank the older sister, a snow fight enses and Sansa slips. What does Arya do?   Her sister came back to see if she was hurt. That is perfectly normal sibling behaviour. As is that the fight continues directly after Sansa tells Arya that she is not hurt! I honestly don’t know how people get the idea that the sisters hate each other…..

I would just alert you to the fact, that there is even more, and that is tropes. And this is really cleverly done. Because with Arya’s and Sansa’s relationship GRRM plays into several ideas in our heads about the Cinderella trope. And we all know, who is the good girl in the Cinderella tale, don’t we?

If you look at it, it is all there, apart from the fact that they are real siblings and not step-sister. The “dirty” sister who gets scolded by the mother, and snubbed by the older sister (or so it seems to Arya), the older sister who is into dance and music and excells in it (and who does not get her hands dirty). In Sansa’s first chapter we see Sansa recoil from a mud-splattered Arya. Also Cinderella-Arya is fond of running, has friends with the servants, you name it. Then there is the father, who favours the “dirty” sister. He is the one that loves Cinderella, and it is only after he dies, that her life becomes hell. I have answered several questions already on Ned and his failure to be as good as a father to Arya as to Sansa.

So these tropes are strong! We are supposed to root for Cinderella - Arya, and this is what we do. How charming that she learns the sword as well! It makes it so easy to like her (and I like her as well, I love Arya, and I loved her before I appreciated Sansa).

Only, GRRM gives us hints that the Cinderella trope is not applicable in Arya’s and Sansa’s case. The prince Sansa expects to marry is a nightmare, the invitation to the Queen’s house (if only the wheelhouse) is not wanted by Cinderella-Arya, the father who loves Cinderella-Arya so much despite her being dirty that he lets her do what she wants, actually dies to save the life of the other daughter.

So, we know that Arya will not get the prince that Sansa was betrothed to. She will not outshine her sister stealing to a ball. But still people expect her to fulfill the other tropes that come with Cinderella: Outshining her sister, displacing her and most of all many people expect Cinderella’s sister to be punished (you know, this is the season Sansa will finally die….) It is a credit to GRRM and his mastery how he manages to lead us by the nose with these tropes.

I would just add, that in Fire and Blood GRRM gives us more hints that we should not take the Cinderella tale at face value. Just look at the end of fire and blood and the absolutely ridiculous subversion of the Cinderella tale! The last pages of Fire and Blood and the ball to get a bride for Aegon III are so over the top that I couldn’t stop laughing.

Tagging @lady-in-a-song for the Cinderella reference….

So, PoV trap, timing of the introduction of Sansa’s PoV, the relatability of Arya and above all tropes, tropes, tropes play into the fandom’s perception of Sansa’s and Arya’s relationship.

I suspect we get some fights in the books as well, but I really hope, it will be better done than the Winterhell plot. What is important to me, is that we will see the sisters having each other’s back in the last season, I’m sure.

Septa Mordane raised her eyes. She had a bony face, sharp eyes, and a thin lipless mouth made for frowning. It was frowning now. “What are you talking about, children?”                 

“Our half brother,” Sansa corrected, soft and precise. She smiled for the septa. “Arya and I were remarking on how pleased we were to have the princess with us today,” she said. (AGOT, Arya I)

Sansa deflects Septa Mordane. She prevents that everyone in the room gets alerted to the fact that Jon and Arya were criticizing the crown prince. She’s got Arya’s back here, but Arya doesn’t realise this.

Anyway, I could go on about this and you are quite right, that we have the incident at the Trident in the first Sansa chapter does not help at all. Some fans refuse to see that deep down Arya and Sansa love each other. I’m sure that @kellyvela and @lostlittlesatellites have explained this and you can check their blogs.

There is the PoV trap, there is the fact, that we see only into Sansa’s head the day the fall-out with her sister happens, and there is the way we are guided by that bastard GRRM to misread and misinterpret the signs that point towards the sisters’ love for each other.

She remembered a summer’s snow in Winterfell when Arya and Bran had ambushed her as she emerged from the keep one morning. They’d each had a dozen snowballs to hand, and she’d had none. Bran had been perched on the roof of the covered bridge, out of reach, but Sansa had chased Arya through the stables and around the kitchen until both of them were breathless. She might even have caught her, but she’d slipped on some ice. Her sister came back to see if she was hurt. When she said she wasn’t, Arya hit her in the face with another snowball, but Sansa grabbed her leg and pulled her down and was rubbing snow in her hair when Jory came along and pulled them apart, laughing. (ASOS, Sansa VII)

This is where you can see it. The younger siblings prank the older sister, a snow fight enses and Sansa slips. What does Arya do?   Her sister came back to see if she was hurt. That is perfectly normal sibling behaviour. As is that the fight continues directly after Sansa tells Arya that she is not hurt! I honestly don’t know how people get the idea that the sisters hate each other…..

I would just alert you to the fact, that there is even more, and that is tropes. And this is really cleverly done. Because with Arya’s and Sansa’s relationship GRRM plays into several ideas in our heads about the Cinderella trope. And we all know, who is the good girl in the Cinderella tale, don’t we?

If you look at it, it is all there, apart from the fact that they are real siblings and not step-sister. The “dirty” sister who gets scolded by the mother, and snubbed by the older sister (or so it seems to Arya), the older sister who is into dance and music and excells in it (and who does not get her hands dirty). In Sansa’s first chapter we see Sansa recoil from a mud-splattered Arya. Also Cinderella-Arya is fond of running, has friends with the servants, you name it. Then there is the father, who favours the “dirty” sister. He is the one that loves Cinderella, and it is only after he dies, that her life becomes hell. I have answered several questions already on Ned and his failure to be as good as a father to Arya as to Sansa.

So these tropes are strong! We are supposed to root for Cinderella - Arya, and this is what we do. How charming that she learns the sword as well! It makes it so easy to like her (and I like her as well, I love Arya, and I loved her before I appreciated Sansa).

Only, GRRM gives us hints that the Cinderella trope is not applicable in Arya’s and Sansa’s case. The prince Sansa expects to marry is a nightmare, the invitation to the Queen’s house (if only the wheelhouse) is not wanted by Cinderella-Arya, the father who loves Cinderella-Arya so much despite her being dirty that he lets her do what she wants, actually dies to save the life of the other daughter.

So, we know that Arya will not get the prince that Sansa was betrothed to. She will not outshine her sister stealing to a ball. But still people expect her to fulfill the other tropes that come with Cinderella: Outshining her sister, displacing her and most of all many people expect Cinderella’s sister to be punished (you know, this is the season Sansa will finally die….) It is a credit to GRRM and his mastery how he manages to lead us by the nose with these tropes.

I would just add, that in Fire and Blood GRRM gives us more hints that we should not take the Cinderella tale at face value. Just look at the end of fire and blood and the absolutely ridiculous subversion of the Cinderella tale! The last pages of Fire and Blood and the ball to get a bride for Aegon III are so over the top that I couldn’t stop laughing.

Tagging @lady-in-a-song for the Cinderella reference….

So, PoV trap, timing of the introduction of Sansa’s PoV, the relatability of Arya and above all tropes, tropes, tropes play into the fandom’s perception of Sansa’s and Arya’s relationship.

I suspect we get some fights in the books as well, but I really hope, it will be better done than the Winterhell plot. What is important to me, is that we will see the sisters having each other’s back in the last season, I’m sure.

summary: [Maisie Williams] appears in the final season which airs in April, and gave a hint of what her character Arya Stark goes...
body:
[Maisie Williams] appears in the final season which airs in April, and gave a hint of what her character Arya Stark goes through.

“The final season, as an actor you try to call on your emotional memories and it meant that for the final season I was really not in a good place and I didn’t want to get better because I didn’t want to not be able to tap into those emotions” [x]

idk im just happy this implies arya will have emotions in s8 😂💀

reblog.comment:

blog.name: thegeekembassy
blog.title: The Geek Embassy
blog.description:
The ambassadors of Geek Embassy endeavor to share all types of geeky passions with our community. As a group, we write individually but we come together to share our collective experiences with different media. For TGE Watches, we talk about movies and TV shows. TGE Plays, we play games together. For TGE Reads, we select a book, read it, and then discuss it together. We are hoping through our collective knowledge and know-how to share these geeky interests with our readers, viewers, and listeners. 

Listen to our podcast at https://www.thegeekembassy.com/category/podcast

summary: Character-Defining Scenes: Arya Stark
title: Character-Defining Scenes: Arya Stark
body:
Character-Defining Scenes: Arya Stark

Each of the remaining major characters in Game of Thrones has a pivotal scene that has changed them from who they were at the beginning of the show to who they are leading into the final season. This scene for Arya Stark comes in episode 8 of season 6.

The Lead Up

Arya has no problems pretending to be someone else. Starting with season 2 she takes on the identity of an orphan boy traveling…

summary: Can we talk about the fact that out of all the Stark's Arya is the only one NOT being smothered by furs, it's almost as if she's...
caption:
Can we talk about the fact that out of all the Stark’s Arya is the only one NOT being smothered by furs, it’s almost as if she’s only wearing her cloak as a statement rather than for warmth.

Also while we’re on the topic Bran looks like a tiny little head stuck on a large mans body, try getting that image out of your head lol

reblog.comment:

Also while we’re on the topic Bran looks like a tiny little head stuck on a large mans body, try getting that image out of your head lol
